items.title: Jacobs Institute SP26 Innovation Catalysts Applications Now Open

Jacobs Institute SP26 Innovation Catalysts Applications Now Open

items.title: Student Opportunity Fund 2025-2026 Application Now Open
items.html:
Student Opportunity Fund 2025-2026 Application Now Open


Application due Monday, Dec 1 at 9AM PST
  • The Student Opportunity Fund provides funding for professional development opportunities for students.
  • Individual students or RSOs can apply to receive up to $2,000 for opportunities outside of the classroom such as:
    • Visiting speakers
    • Forums on topics of general interest
    • Conferences
  • The deadline for Fall 2025 applications is for any opportunity taking place between Jul 1, 2025 and Dec 31, 2025.
    • The application will open again in Spring for opportunities taking place between Jan 1, 2026 and Jun 30, 2026
  • Apply for the Student Opportunity Fund via Google Form.
    • To learn more about SOF's criteria, eligibility, and FAQs, please review the Student Opportunity Funds Guide

items.title: Climate Solutions Fund Pitch Day
items.html:
Climate Solutions Fund Pitch Day


Friday, Nov 21, 9AM - 1PM PST, Spieker Forum, Haas School of Business
  • The Sustainable and Impact Finance Initiative will host the second Pitch Day for the Berkeley Haas Climate Solutions Fund.
  • Teams of student investment manager role will have the opportunity to present their investment opportunities to complete for a $300K investment from the Climate Solutions Fund.

items.title: UC LAUNCH Demo Day
items.html:
UC LAUNCH Demo Day


Tuesday, Dec 2, 10AM - 1:30PM PST, Spieker Forum, Haas School of Business
  • Watch top teams from UC LAUNCH pitch their ideas to judges to compete for up to $60K in prizes.
  • Attendees will also have the chance to network with founders, investors, and potential mentors.
  • Registration for UC Launch Demo Day is now available via Luma.
  • Please note that as of Nov 20, tickets are officially sold out. However, a waitlist is available.

    • Waitlisted attendees will still be able to join the networking portion

items.title: Pathways Forward: Building Your Job Search Strategy Post-Layoff
items.html:
Pathways Forward: Building Your Job Search Strategy Post-Layoff


Tuesdays Dec 2 & 9; 12-1:15PM PST, CMG Bears
  • Have you recently been impacted by layoffs and are wondering how to get started on finding your next role? Are you looking for guidance and support from career professionals and your peers? This workshop series is for you!
  • Focusing on those aiming to stay within their current function or industry, these workshops offer a structured, action-oriented approach to jump-starting your job search. This series is not for those who are looking to make big changes and pivots, but to help you find a role aligned with your skills or industry.
  • During the sessions you will:
    • retouch your resume
    • develop a list of target companies
    • set up a networking outreach tracker to keep your efforts organized and effective
  • Attendance in Part 1 (Dec 2 from 12:00-1:15 PM) is a prerequisite for Part 2 (Dec 9 from 12:00-1:15 PM)
  • These are highly interactive workshops with small group breakouts; please only sign up if your schedule allows you to actively participate with your camera on.

items.title: Transferable Skills
items.html:
Transferable Skills


Wednesday, Dec 3, 12PM - 1PM PST, CMG Bears
  • This workshop will help you describe your accomplishments in a way that your new audience can easily understand.
    • Reframe your experience such that people in different industries/roles/organizations understand its value
  • Through lectures, individual and small group activities, and Q&A, you will learn to:
    • Explicitly talk about your transferable skills
    • Elevate your skills-based stories by making them applicable to another role, organization, or industry

items.title: Planning Ahead for Spring 2026 fees
items.html:
Planning Ahead for Spring 2026 fees




How to Calculate the Spring 2026 Fees
  • The all inclusive per unit fee for 2025-2026 is $3,972. Multiply that by the number of units you will be taking.
  • Spring 2026 tuition will be due in Jan. Enrollment in the Fee Payment Plan is per semester, not per year. Students must enroll in the plan again for Spring 2026.
Setting up your Direct Deposit Account
  • A Direct Deposit Electronic Funds Transfer Account is the easiest way to get refunds or other payments.
  • Go to CalCentral > My Finances > Financial Resources > Billing & Payments > Direct Deposit. Complete the steps to set up your account.
1098-T Form
  • Students will receive notification that their 1098-T form is read by the end of Jan 2026. More information here on the Student Billing website.

blue.title: Teams@Haas Collaborative Plan Submission (EWMBA Blue) [Teams@Haas 2025]
blue.description:
The Collaborative Plans are designed to support your team in developing a shared understanding of how you will work together and how you will cultivate a collaborative team climate that will support each other's development.

Milestones:

* Access & Copy: [Collaborative Planning Template] (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1O6p6HoxX-hpzLsnWoEdzwqCkDLmpDABlh2IbXewHXvs/edit?usp=sharing)

* Share: Collaborative Plan with all team members

* Organize Team Meeting: Identify a time after your first set of classes to meet with your team to align on all of your agreements. 

* Complete Collaborative Plan: fill in all three sections (Goal Alignment (A&B), Knowledge Coordination, Collaborative Climate) based on your agreements from the WE | Launch workshops & follow-up meeting.

* Upload: Collaborative Plan to bCourse by the deadline for your cohort

Note: you can copy and paste the photo from the Value Map with your agreed-upon norms and practices from WE | Launch

Upload Instructions

* Upload Plan Under the Assignment Tab

* 1 Plan Per Team

* File Name Convention = Team Number_Collaborative Plan (i.e. 405_Collaborative Plan)

NOTE:  The Team Collaborative Plan is for your reference. During the Teams@Haas Check-In Workshop #1, your team will have time to update and pivot on your plan based on what you learn about the nature of your work and each other as you work together. More to follow on this in the weeks to come.

blue.title: Teams@Haas Check-In  Workshop #1 (Executive Coach) (EWMBA Blue) [Teams@Haas 2025]
blue.description:
A critical component of effective teamwork is reflexivity (Schippers et al., 2003).  Reflexivity is a group's ability to collectively reflect upon team objectives, strategies, and processes and to adapt them accordingly. This is our primary goal for the Teams@Haas Team Check-in Workshop. 

Your teams will have the opportunity to engage in this practice during the Teams@Haas Team Check-In facilitated by a Teams@Haas Executive Coaching Team.  The goal of these workshops is to provide you and your team with a new set of tools and to also support you in facilitating a conversation for your team to step back and reflect on what is working well and where you might make adaptations for improved effectiveness.

Prior to the Team Check-In Workshop, please:

* Check Your Team's Workshop Time (no Berkeley time) & Location

* Review your Team Collaborative Plan 

* Watch: [HIT Team Check-In Plenary Video] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1535656/pages/video-team-check-in)

Participation Grade: Attendance for this session is part of your Leading People participation grade.

blue.title: Team Preferences for Case Preparation & Leadership Assignment
blue.description:
We will be using several cases to illustrate key marketing concepts this semester and deepen your understanding of the real-world business situations where marketers apply them. All of the cases are in the Study.Net reader. All are required reading and students should be prepared to discuss them in class.

This is your chance to decide as a team which case you want to focus on for the Case Preparation & Leadership Assignment. Two teams will be responsible for: (1) leading the class discussion of the key issues in the case, (2) writing a 3 page recap of their findings and recommendations, and (3) posting and monitoring a discussion board thread about the aspect of the case they are focusing on. One team will tackle the case from a company/competitive perspective and the other from a customer/consumer point of view.

Click here (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfAx2ONcz6CF1ghWfKD8t6iBEygSTZaikBwqak3Iy22MedhSg/viewform?usp=sharing&ouid=113674834595072819528) to see the questions to be addressed by the team responsible for our discussion of each case. Then, agree as a team on your top 3 choices and fill out this short preferences survey (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfAx2ONcz6CF1ghWfKD8t6iBEygSTZaikBwqak3Iy22MedhSg/viewform?usp=header). After submitting your response, have one team member upload the confirmation page to bCourses.

Teams will be assigned a case if they do not submit their preferences by Friday, Oct 17.

Due: Friday Oct 17 by 11:59pm
Points: 0
Available: Oct 8 at 12am - Oct 17 at 11:59pm

blue.title: Teams@Haas Check-In Workshop #2 (Self-Facilitated) (EWMBA Blue) [Teams@Haas 2025]
blue.description:
A critical component of effective teamwork is reflexivity (Schippers et al., 2003).  Reflexivity is a group's ability to collectively reflect upon team objectives, strategies, and processes and to adapt them accordingly. 

All academic teams are asked to complete a Self-Facilitated Team Check-In Workshop as they launch Fall B.  During this workshop, you will develop a Team Collaborative Map and ratify joint agreements to support your team in its next stage of development. 

Please identify one team member who will serve as the facilitator for this workshop and who will be responsible for uploading a photo of the Collaborative Map from the team's self-facilitated check-in. 

TEAM CHECK-IN #2 WORKSHOP SELF-FACILITATED LOGISTICS :

Timing: Schedule a team meeting and allow a minimum of 75 minutes (90 minutes preferred) to complete the process and ratify one or more joint agreements. 

Facilitation: Select one team member to serve as the facilitator. This person will be responsible for 1) preparing in advance by reviewing the process and objectives for each stage and pulling up the top three agreements from Check-In #1, 2) guiding the team through the entire workshop, 3) ensuring communication during the workshop is balanced (i.e., everyone has an opportunity to share and listen), 4) supporting the team in reaching 1-3 joint agreements in support of your team’s continued development and 5) uploading a photo of the Collaborative Map to bCourse by 10/24.  

Supplies:

* For an in-person check-in, teams will need a large whiteboard or easel pad, sticky notes, and markers. Kits with the needed supplies will be available in the MBA Lounge. Please return the kits to the lounge after using them so other teams can use them. 

* For a virtual check-in, teams can use the Zoom whiteboard function to create a collaborative map to support your brainstorming & discussion. 

Resources:

* [Check-In Video:] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1546457/pages/video-team-check-in) Refresher on the purpose of a Team Check-In.

* [Self-Facilitated Check-In Deck:] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1546457/files/92053866?wrap=1) Provides detailed facilitation instructions

* [Note:] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1546457/files/92053931?wrap=1) An Overview of Giving and Receiving Reflective Feedback in Teams

Submission

* Photo of Collaborative Map with Team Agreements (1/team)

blue.description:
At the end of your academic team journey, your team will be asked to self-facilitate a Team Debrief Workshop. 

Please identify one member of the team who is responsible for submitting a photo of your Team Journey Map and providing a reflection of your team journey based on one of the prompts outlined below that emerged in your discussions—no more than one paragraph required.  

Please select one of the prompts below and share your reflections:

* Please share one way your team developed either intentionally or unintentionally during your team journey, and what actions team members took to support this development?

* What were some of the benefits and challenges of working with a team of people from different disciplines, lived experiences, and cultures?  How did this contribute to the leadership development of the team members?

gold.title: Teams@Haas Check-In  Workshop #1 (Executive Coach) (EWMBA Blue) [Teams@Haas 2025]
gold.description:
A critical component of effective teamwork is reflexivity (Schippers et al., 2003).  Reflexivity is a group's ability to collectively reflect upon team objectives, strategies, and processes and to adapt them accordingly. This is our primary goal for the Teams@Haas Team Check-in Workshop. 

Your teams will have the opportunity to engage in this practice during the Teams@Haas Team Check-In facilitated by a Teams@Haas Executive Coaching Team.  The goal of these workshops is to provide you and your team with a new set of tools and to also support you in facilitating a conversation for your team to step back and reflect on what is working well and where you might make adaptations for improved effectiveness.

Prior to the Team Check-In Workshop, please:

* Check Your Team's Workshop Time (no Berkeley time) & Location

* Review your Team Collaborative Plan 

* Watch: [HIT Team Check-In Plenary Video] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1535656/pages/video-team-check-in)

Participation Grade: Attendance for this session is part of your Leading People participation grade.

gold.title: Team Preferences for Case Preparation & Leadership Assignment
gold.description:
We will be using several cases to illustrate key marketing concepts this semester and deepen your understanding of the real-world business situations where marketers apply them. All of the cases are in the Study.Net reader. All are required reading and students should be prepared to discuss them in class.

This is your chance to decide as a team which case you want to focus on for the Case Preparation & Leadership Assignment. Two teams will be responsible for: (1) leading the class discussion of the key issues in the case, (2) writing a 3 page recap of their findings and recommendations, and (3) posting and monitoring a discussion board thread about the aspect of the case they are focusing on. One team will tackle the case from a company/competitive perspective and the other from a customer/consumer point of view.

Click here (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfAx2ONcz6CF1ghWfKD8t6iBEygSTZaikBwqak3Iy22MedhSg/viewform?usp=sharing&ouid=113674834595072819528) to see the questions to be addressed by the team responsible for our discussion of each case. Then, agree as a team on your top 3 choices and fill out this short preferences survey (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfAx2ONcz6CF1ghWfKD8t6iBEygSTZaikBwqak3Iy22MedhSg/viewform?usp=header). After submitting your response, have one team member upload the confirmation page to bCourses.

Teams will be assigned a case if they do not submit their preferences by Friday, Oct 17.

Due: Friday Oct 17 by 11:59pm
Points: 0
Available: Oct 8 at 12am - Oct 17 at 11:59pm

gold.title: Teams@Haas Check-In Workshop #2 (Self-Facilitated) (EWMBA Blue) [Teams@Haas 2025]
gold.description:
A critical component of effective teamwork is reflexivity (Schippers et al., 2003).  Reflexivity is a group's ability to collectively reflect upon team objectives, strategies, and processes and to adapt them accordingly. 

All academic teams are asked to complete a Self-Facilitated Team Check-In Workshop as they launch Fall B.  During this workshop, you will develop a Team Collaborative Map and ratify joint agreements to support your team in its next stage of development. 

Please identify one team member who will serve as the facilitator for this workshop and who will be responsible for uploading a photo of the Collaborative Map from the team's self-facilitated check-in. 

TEAM CHECK-IN #2 WORKSHOP SELF-FACILITATED LOGISTICS :

Timing: Schedule a team meeting and allow a minimum of 75 minutes (90 minutes preferred) to complete the process and ratify one or more joint agreements. 

Facilitation: Select one team member to serve as the facilitator. This person will be responsible for 1) preparing in advance by reviewing the process and objectives for each stage and pulling up the top three agreements from Check-In #1, 2) guiding the team through the entire workshop, 3) ensuring communication during the workshop is balanced (i.e., everyone has an opportunity to share and listen), 4) supporting the team in reaching 1-3 joint agreements in support of your team’s continued development and 5) uploading a photo of the Collaborative Map to bCourse by 10/24.  

Supplies:

* For an in-person check-in, teams will need a large whiteboard or easel pad, sticky notes, and markers. Kits with the needed supplies will be available in the MBA Lounge. Please return the kits to the lounge after using them so other teams can use them. 

* For a virtual check-in, teams can use the Zoom whiteboard function to create a collaborative map to support your brainstorming & discussion. 

Resources:

* [Check-In Video:] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1546457/pages/video-team-check-in) Refresher on the purpose of a Team Check-In.

* [Self-Facilitated Check-In Deck:] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1546457/files/92053866?wrap=1) Provides detailed facilitation instructions

* [Note:] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1546457/files/92053931?wrap=1) An Overview of Giving and Receiving Reflective Feedback in Teams

Submission

* Photo of Collaborative Map with Team Agreements (1/team)

original.title: Class 1 - Group Facilitators Johnsonville Case Memo (EWMBA 205 LEC 01A (In Person)) [EWMBA 205-LEC-01A & 02A FA25]
original.description:
Case: Johnsonville Sausage Co.
You have been consulted by Ralph Stayer to make recommendations on what to do about the Palmer request. Your recommendation (including the three points below) should be in the form of a memo to Ralph. It should be one page maximum (single-spaced, 12-point font, Times New Roman, and 1-inch margins).

As a facilitator, you’ll use the preparation of this memo to help kick off and guide your group’s discussion. You won’t need to present your memo in full, but it should give you a clear point of view and framing to engage your teammates. Please remember: if you haven’t done the readings or submitted your memo, you won’t be equipped to lead your group and you’ll be letting your team down.

Ralph wants to see the following in your memo:

1. A clear and succinct understanding of the key challenge(s) he faces in the situation, supported by case facts/observations.

2. The pros/cons of various alternatives available and guidance on how the decision should be made.

3. A strong rationale for your recommended action, based upon (1) and (2) above. 

To support your thinking, you should also reflect on the following questions as you prepare:

*

Has Ralph made the transition from entrepreneurial to professional management?

*

What forces led to that transition?

*

What options does he have now?

*

How does a leader know when it’s time to make this kind of shift?

 

Submission Details:

*

Due: On bCourses by 6:00 PM on the day of class

*

Format: Type directly into the submission box

*

Grading: You will receive a grade out of 5 points based on the quality and effort demonstrated in your memo. See rubric posted below.

Good luck and have fun!

original.title: Team Assignment: Corporate Memo (Part 1)  [EWMBA 201A-LEC-01A & 02A FA25]
original.description:
Much of the work of business takes place in teams. To enhance your experience with teams and with your classmates, you will be asked to write a short memo analyzing a company’s cost structure and pricing policies. The details about this team assignment can be found below. You have to work on this assignment with the study group you have been assigned to.

Only one member per study group has to upload the PDF with the team's pricing project to bCourses. For more detailed instructions, read the following page:

[Pricing Project Directions] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1544880/pages/team-assignment-corporate-memo-instructions)

As the first checkpoint, your team will need to submit the name of the company and one introductory paragraph about what the company does. You should seek for approval on the name of the company in advance -- I want to make sure that there is no more than one team working on each company.

Note that this assignment (i.e., the first checkpoint) is not graded. However, you are expected to submit the assignment on time. Failing to deliver will result in a 10-point deduction from the final assignment grade.

original.title: Class 2 - Group Facilitators Cirque Case Memo (EWMBA 205 LEC 01A (In Person)) [EWMBA 205-LEC-01A & 02A FA25]
original.description:
Case: Cirque du Soleil

Guy Laliberte, Cirque's CEO, has consulted you to advise him on how to navigate the company’s future growth. Your recommendation (including points 1-3 from below) should be in the form of a memo to Guy. It should be one page maximum (single-spaced, 12-point font, Times New Roman, and 1-inch margins).

As a facilitator, you’ll use the preparation of this memo to help kick off and guide your group’s discussion. You won’t need to present your memo in full, but it should give you a clear point of view and framing to engage your teammates. Please remember: if you haven’t done the readings or submitted your memo, you won’t be equipped to lead your group and you’ll be letting your team down.

Guy wants to see the following in your memo:

1. A clear and succinct understanding of the key challenge(s) he faces in the situation. Your support of the challenges should include case facts/observations.

2. The pros/cons of various alternatives available for planning for the future. 

3. A strong rationale for your recommended action, based upon (1) and (2) above. 

To support your thinking, consider the following questions as you prepare:

*

What are the artists’ greatest sources of motivation for their work?

*

How does Cirque keep staff motivated when the spotlight is on the performers?

*

Reflect on your own experiences working in organizations where you were either “staff” or “star.”

*

What lessons might Cirque learn from an investment bank? A tech company like Nvidia? A research laboratory?

Submission Details:

*

* Due: On bCourses by 6:00 PM on the day of class

*

Format: Type directly into the submission box

*

Grading: You will receive a grade out of 5 points based on the quality and effort demonstrated in your memo. See rubric posted below.

Good luck and have fun!

original.title: Class 3 - Group Facilitators Yelp Case Memo (EWMBA 205 LEC 01A (In Person)) [EWMBA 205-LEC-01A & 02A FA25]
original.description:
Case: Managing Diversity and Inclusion at Yelp

You have been consulted by Rachel Williams, Head of Diversity and Inclusion at Yelp, to provide a recommendation on how she should move forward in designing Yelp’s first company-wide DEI strategy. Your recommendation (including the three points below) should be in the form of a memo to Rachel. It should be one page maximum (single-spaced, 12-point font, Times New Roman, and 1-inch margins).

As a facilitator, you’ll use this memo to help kick off and guide your group’s discussion. You don’t need to present the full memo, but it should help you frame the central challenge and open up conversation. Please remember: if you haven’t done the readings or submitted your memo, you won’t be equipped to lead your group and you’ll be letting your team down.

Rachel wants to see the following in your memo:

*

A clear and succinct understanding of the core challenge(s) facing Yelp when it comes to building a more diverse and inclusive workforce.

*

The pros and cons of various strategies Rachel could propose to Yelp leadership.

*

A strong rationale for your recommendation, based on (1) and (2), as well as insights from the case and readings.

To support your thinking, consider the following guiding questions:

*

Why isn’t there more diversity among engineers at Yelp and in tech companies more broadly?

*

Where in the hiring funnel might bias be showing up (e.g., sourcing, selection, socialization)?

*

How should Yelp evaluate whether its inclusion strategies are working over time?

*

How would you advise Yelp to communicate its DEI goals in the current political climate?

Submission Details:

*

* Due: On bCourses by 6:00 PM on the day of class

*

Format: Type directly into the submission box

*

Grading: You will receive a grade out of 5 points based on the quality and effort demonstrated in your memo. See rubric posted below.

Good luck and have fun!

Note that this assignment (i.e., second checkpoint) is not graded. However, you are expected to submit the assignment on time. Failing to deliver will result in a 10-point deduction from the final assignment grade.

original.title: Part 1 - Interview Report  [EWMBA 205-LEC-01A & 02A FA25]
original.description:
Your team's task is to create a profile of a leader, analyzing their strengths and weaknesses. Conduct an interview with your team’s choice of a leader (any level, any type) and at least one person who reports to that leader, and to use as many other methods as you can, to learn about that person. Your final product will be a maximum of 1800 words (adhering to 1.5 spacing, 12-point Times New Roman font, and 1-inch margins). 

 

The report should cover three key aspects: 1)What makes your chosen interviewee a leader, 2) an assessment of their strengths and weaknesses, and 3) constructive advice to help improve their situation. 

 

The goal of this assignment is to deepen your understanding of course concepts by exploring leadership in practical settings. It also offers an opportunity to practice delivering honest and constructive feedback. Integrate relevant course concepts from lectures and readings, and feel free to supplement your analysis with high-quality external research. Creativity is encouraged in the style and presentation of your report, including the use of pictures and engaging headings. When selecting a leader to interview, be prepared to justify what makes this person a leader (i.e., Are they a leader through position and/or hierarchy? Are they a beloved and respected member of their community?).

 

As MBA students, I challenge you to rethink your perceptions of leadership. While you all possess leadership qualities worthy of being interviewed, you must all be willing to grow and change as leaders, especially as your rank, positions, or managerial responsibilities continue to evolve. One significant way to achieve this growth is by learning from and critically analyzing other leaders' experiences.

 

Please read the [full assignment details] (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1FZloXH8r04sYvPSFiwXLmO8KW8nLCyWbfuOUU69kakQ/edit) and review the [rubric] (https://bcourses.berkeley.edu/courses/1545386/files/92116296?wrap=1).

original.title: Class 6 - Group Facilitators MediSys Case Memo (EWMBA 205 LEC 01A (In Person)) [EWMBA 205-LEC-01A & 02A FA25]
original.description:
Case: MediSys Corp.: The IntensCare Product Development Team

You have been consulted by Valerie Merz, the marketing manager responsible for the success of the IntensCare product, to help her overcome the problems facing the team. Consider an action plan that Merz can follow, one that thoughtfully considers the costs and benefits of your proposed approach.Your recommendation (including points 1-3 from below) should be in the form of a memo to Merz.  It should be one page maximum (single-spaced, 12-point font, Times New Roman, and 1-inch margins).

As a facilitator, you’ll use the preparation of this memo to help kick off and guide your group’s discussion. You won’t need to present your memo in full, but it should give you a clear point of view and framing to engage your teammates. Please remember: if you haven’t done the readings or submitted your memo, you won’t be equipped to lead your group and you’ll be letting your team down.

Valerie wants to see the following in your memo:

1. A clear and succinct understanding of the key challenge(s) he faces in the situation. Your support of the challenges should include case facts/observations.

2. The pros/cons of various alternatives available for addressing the challenge.

3. A strong rationale for your recommended action, based upon (1) and (2) above.

To support your thinking, consider the following questions:

*

What factors are contributing to the tensions and dysfunctions on the IntensCare team?

*

How do organizational design choices (functional roles, reporting lines, evaluation systems) shape team dynamics?

*

How could Valerie influence others without formal authority?

*

Have you ever been on a team like this—where power and responsibility were unclear? What worked or didn’t?

Submission Details:

* Due: On bCourses by 6:00 PM on the day of class

*

Format: Type directly into the submission box

*

Grading: You will receive a grade out of 5 points based on the quality and effort demonstrated in your memo. See rubric posted below.

Good luck and have fun!

original.title: Class 8 - Group Facilitators Iggy's Case Memo (EWMBA 205 LEC 01A (In Person)) [EWMBA 205-LEC-01A & 02A FA25]
original.description:
Case: Iggy's Bread of the World

You are a board member/trusted advisor making recommendations to the Ivanovics regarding both McRae's proposal and the problems unfolding that the Ivanovics need to deal with to continue to be successful. Your recommendation (including points 1-3 below) should be in the form of a memo to Iggy + Ludmilla.  It should be one page maximum (single-spaced, 12-point font, Times New Roman, and 1-inch margins).

As a facilitator, you’ll use the preparation of this memo to help kick off and guide your group’s discussion. You won’t need to present your memo in full, but it should give you a clear point of view and framing to engage your teammates. Please remember: if you haven’t done the readings or submitted your memo, you won’t be equipped to lead your group and you’ll be letting your team down.

Iggy + Ludmilla want to see the following in your memo:

1. A clear and succinct understanding of the key challenges they face in the situation. Your support of the challenges should include case facts/observations.

2. The pros/cons of various alternatives available for addressing the challenges.

3. A strong rationale for your recommended action, based upon (1) and (2) above. Not only should your recommendation be supported based upon the facts of the case and your expert knowledge (the “why”), but also your recommendation should include the “who, what, when, and how”.

To support your thinking, reflect on these questions:

*

What values have the Ivanovics instilled in Iggy’s culture, and how have they used direct, indirect, and symbolic influence to shape it?

*

What’s at stake in their current conflict with McRae? What’s driving the breakdown?

*

What’s your assessment of McRae’s role? Could the situation be repaired, or should they move on? If so, what’s next?

Submission Details:

* Due: On bCourses by 6:00 PM on the day of class

*

Format: Type directly into the submission box

*

Grading: You will receive a grade out of 5 points based on the quality and effort demonstrated in your memo. See rubric posted below.

Good luck and have fun baking up a plan! 🥖

campusGroups.title: One Day. Two Fairs: Haas GRSO Club Fair & Centers & Institute Fair!
campusGroups.location: Spieker Forum and Haas Courtyard, 2220 Piedmont Ave, S420, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
campusGroups.description:
Mark your calendars for a jam-packed opportunity of exploration and networking - TWO FAIRS, ONE DAY!

Double your opportunity to enhance leadership development and networking experiences.

The Fairs will allow you to explore the professional groups and communities you can join to further your career search. Through their Club and Centers affiliations, your peers have discovered alumni connections, internship leads, case competitions, and research projects

There's something for everyone, from industry and professional clubs to fun and recreational groups.  


Join us on September 2 from 4-6pm for:

Haas MBA Club Fair in Spieker Forum (4-6pm): Discover over 50 student organizations at Berkeley Haas, offering opportunities for professional growth, community engagement, and socializing. Find your niche and get involved with clubs aligned with your interests!
Haas Centers & Institutes Fair in the Haas Courtyard (4-6pm): Explore innovative hubs for cutting-edge research, collaboration, and impact. Get a sneak peek into the work of our centers and institutes.
Meet us at the following designated times to explore both fairs:

Oski & Gold:
4:00 PM - Club Fair in Spieker Forum
5:00 PM - Centers & Institutes in the Haas Courtyard
Axe & Blue:
4:00 PM - Centers & Institutes in the Haas Courtyard
5:00 PM - Club Fair in Spieker Forum

Find your place! Take some time to learn about the various clubs and organizations that you have the opportunity to join through Haas. We look forward to seeing you there!
